;;2023 年 10 月 26 日，在以色列北部以色列与黎巴嫩边境附近举行军事演习时，一名以色列士兵坐在一辆坦克里。 REUTERS/ Lisi Niesner;
;

;经济陷入废墟，国家摇摇欲坠，黎巴嫩无力承受;真主党;和以色列。

;

;伊朗支持的真主党知道这一点，并牢记黎巴嫩的危机消息人士称，它正在规划与以色列冲突的下一步。

;

;正如;以色列和真主党的巴勒斯坦盟友哈马斯之间的战争在整个中东地区引起反响，真主党和以色列之间发生战争的风险仍然比上次大战以来的任何时候都要高2006 年的冲突。

;

;分析人士表示，如果哈马斯似乎在 200 公里（130 英里）外的加沙地带陷入困境，什叶派组织可能会升级，而黎巴嫩领导人则担心以色列可能会选择煽动一场冲突。与真主党发生重大冲突。

;

;但以色列警告真主党，这将给以色列造成“破坏”。黎巴嫩是打开前线的组织，在这个已经经历了 1975-90 年内战以来最不稳定的阶段之一的国家，任何战争的代价都将变得巨大。

;

;“真主党对战争没有兴趣. 黎巴嫩对战争没有兴趣”，一位熟悉真主党想法的消息人士称。

;

;消息人士称，该组织不希望看到该国被摧毁，黎巴嫩人也像数千人一样逃离南部。< /p>;

;由于国库空空，许多人还想知道谁会支付重建费用。鉴于真主党在黎巴嫩发挥着更大的作用，一些人质疑 2006 年为重建提供资金的逊尼派领导的海湾阿拉伯国家这次是否会急于提供帮助。

;

;真主党与以色列军队在边境的冲突已经得到调整;到目前为止，为了避免局势大幅升级;，尽管有超过 40其战士已被杀害。

;

;然而，真主党也表示;做好战争准备;，反映出其作为伊朗支持的针对以色列和美国的联盟先锋的地位。

;

;黎巴嫩政界人士敦促真主党不要升级，尽管他们对其决定几乎没有影响。

;

;德鲁兹领导人瓦利德·琼布拉特表示，“黎巴嫩的命运岌岌可危”，他称这可能是他认为最危险的阶段。这是他在政治生涯中所看到的。

;

;他说黎巴嫩人无法采取任何措施来阻止以色列挑起的战争。

;

;“但从我们这边来看，我们必须通过对话来控制局势并建议真主党兄弟保持现有的交战规则，”他在向媒体发表评论时说。

;

;以色列总统艾萨克·赫尔佐格表示，以色列并不希望在其北部边境发生对抗，“但是如果真主党把我们拖入战争，黎巴嫩显然会付出代价”。

;

;真主党最亲密的盟友之一、基督教政治家苏莱曼·弗兰吉周三表示，该组织不希望发生战争。他说，如果是的话，真主党武装分子将在 10 月 7 日袭击以色列，就像哈马斯从加沙袭击以色列一样。

;

;黎巴嫩一名高级官员表示，各国政府已与黎巴嫩联系以缓和紧张局势。

;

;他说：“我们告诉他们，他们不需要让我们限制真主党，而是需要向以色列施加压力，让其不要升级。”

;

;过去几年对黎巴嫩来说尤其困难，该国自独立以来一直缺乏稳定，并经历了战争，包括 1978 年和 1982 年以色列的入侵。

;

;执政政客数十年的腐败和管理不善导致金融体系在 2019 年崩溃，储蓄消失，货币崩溃，并助长了经济衰退。贫困。

;

;第二年，贝鲁特因港口发生的一次巨大化学品爆炸而支离破碎。真主党利用其影响力帮助破坏了一项旨在起诉其一些盟友的调查，称其政治化。紧张局势导致了致命的暴力。

;

;国家几乎无法运转，而派系争吵使其失去了总统和充分授权的政府。

;

;Nabil Boumonsef，副总编辑《安娜哈尔报》称，任何战争的破坏性都会比 2006 年大得多，而黎巴嫩没有一个有能力管理其后果的政府。

;

;“我们将面临真正的恐怖场景 - 整个国家被毁。黎巴嫩的基础设施建设并毁掉了任何经济复苏的前景。”他说。

;

;黎巴嫩花了数年时间才从 2006 年的战争中重建，这场战争导致黎巴嫩 1,200 人死亡，其中大部分是平民，还有 158 名以色列人死亡，其中大部分是士兵。真主党在一次跨境袭击中绑架了两名以色列士兵并杀害了其他人，战争结束后，真主党领导人赛义德·哈桑·纳斯鲁拉表示，该组织没有预见到战争，如果他知道这会导致这样的冲突。

;

;十七年后，真主党大规模扩张的军火库巩固了对自己有利的权力平衡，这令反对者感到沮丧，他们说真主党再次决定战争问题和和平。

;

;“他们在发号施令。这是完全不可接受的，”坚决反对真主党的基督教派别黎巴嫩力量党的主要成员加桑·哈斯巴尼说。

;

;“人们严重担心黎巴嫩被真主党拖入破坏性对抗，卡内基中东中心的 Mohanad Hage Ali 表示，真主党将认真考虑重建后如何筹集资金。任何战争，人们都会质疑海湾阿拉伯国家是否会提供帮助以及伊朗可以提供多少现金。

;

;“如果不进行重建，该组织肯定会付出政治代价......人们会提出问题，并且将会引起广泛的愤怒。”

; Thu, 26 Oct 2023 22:55:03 +0800 US third-quarter economic growth seen fastest in nearly 2 yearshttps://reuters.com/article/usa-economy/consumers-power-us-economy-in-third-quarter-idUSKBN31Q09J
;;2023-10-26T04:04:48Z;
;;
;;2022 年 3 月 29 日，美国纽约市布鲁克林的一家商店展示水果和蔬菜的价格。REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/档案照片;
;

;美国经济第三季度可能以近两年来最快的速度增长，再次无视经济衰退的可怕警告，因为紧缩的工资导致工资上涨劳动力市场帮助推动了消费者支出。

;

;美国商务部周四对第三季度国内生产总值的预先估计也预计将显示住宅投资在连续九个季度下降后出现反弹。随着工厂建设的提振作用逐渐减弱，商业投资据信已经放缓。乔·拜登总统的政府已采取措施鼓励美国增加半导体制造

;

;虽然上个季度预期的强劲增长速度可能无法持续，但这将证明尽管美联储大幅加息，经济仍具有韧性预订。尽管如此，由于美国汽车工人联合会罢工和数百万美国人恢复学生贷款偿还，第四季度的增长可能会放缓。

;

;大多数经济学家都;修改了他们的预测;，现在相信美联储可以设计“软着陆” “对于经济而言，预期 7 月至 9 月期间将显示第二季度工人生产率将持续强劲，单位劳动力成本将有所放缓。

;

;“我们看到的情况恰恰相反（即多伦多 BMO 资本市场高级经济学家萨尔·瓜蒂耶里 (Sal Guatieri) 表示。 “作为美国经济最大引擎的美国消费者似乎在年中复苏，主要是因为整个夏季股市上涨和汽油价格稳定，信心有所改善。”

;

;路透社对经济学家的调查显示，上季度 GDP 折年率可能增长 4.3%，这将是 2021 年第四季度以来最快的。4 月至 6 月季度经济增长 2.1%，扩张速度为这一速度远高于美联储官员所认为的约 1.8% 的非通胀增长率。;

;预估范围从低至 2.5% 到高达 6.0%，反映了较大幅度的差距一些输入数据，包括9月份耐用品订单、货物贸易赤字、批发和零售库存数据将与GDP报告同时公布。

;

;消费者支出，占GDP的比重超过两倍美国经济活动的三分之一可能是主要驱动力，美国人购买机动车辆等耐用商品以及参加音乐会。由于价格下降，商品支出似乎大幅增加。

;

;强劲的劳动力市场支撑了消费者支出。尽管工资增长放缓，但其增长速度略快于通胀，从而提高了家庭的购买力。消费者支出增速预计将超过 4.0%，第二季度仅增长 0.8%。

;

;学生贷款偿还额于 10 月份恢复，经济学家估计约为 700 亿美元，或个人可支配收入的 0.3% 左右，并可能减少支出。尽管疫情期间积累的超额储蓄仍然充足，但主要集中在高收入家庭。

;

;低收入消费者越来越依赖债务来为购买提供资金，借贷成本上升导致信用卡拖欠率上升。< /p>;

;因此，一些经济学家认为经济即将大幅放缓。其他人并不太担心，他们指出劳动力市场继续强劲地创造就业机会。

;

;“我们看到有关信用卡债务增长过快的可怕头条新闻，但在大流行期间已经下降了很多”，费城威尔明顿信托公司首席经济学家卢克·蒂利说。 “当你把它看作人们每月收入的一部分时，它实际上是相当正常的。我认为我们还没有达到煤矿里的金丝雀的地步。”

;

;劳工部周四发布的另一份报告应能体现出劳动力市场的韧性，该报告预计上周初请失业金人数将较前一周的九个月低点小幅上升。

;

;GDP数据可能不会影响短期货币政策，因为随着美国国债收益率飙升而股市下跌，金融状况已经收紧。

;

;金融市场预计美联储将维持利率不变10月31日至11月31日不变根据芝商所 (CME Group) 的 FedWatch 数据，1 日政策会议。自3月份以来，美联储自2022年3月起已将基准隔夜利率上调525个基点，至目前的5.25%至5.50%区间。

;

;“我认为（强劲的GDP报告）已经融入他们的思维，”法国巴黎银行驻纽约的高级经济学家叶莲娜·舒利亚蒂耶娃(Yelena Shulyatyeva)说。 “我们认为，我们已经达到了这个商业周期的最终速度。”

;

;由于出口强劲和库存投资增加，贸易逆差较小也提振了上季度的增长。预计九月中旬开始的汽车罢工不会产生影响。但劳资纠纷每周给汽车制造商造成数百万美元的损失，可能会影响第四季度的增长。

;

;“我认为罢工导致了增速放缓，”经济学家布赖恩·贝休恩 (Brian Bethune) 表示。波士顿学院教授。 “但我不认为我们会突然被扔到海里。”

;;破产的加密货币交易所 FTX 的创始人 Sam Bankman-Fried 抵达法庭，律师正在努力说服监督其欺诈案的法官不要这样做2023 年 8 月 11 日，美国纽约法院在审判前将他监禁。路透社/Eduardo Munoz//档案照片;
;

;FTX 创始人 Sam Bankman-Fried 的律师团启动在经过 12 天的检方证词后，周四，他的欺诈案得到了审理，现已破产的加密货币交易所的前同事表示，他指示他们将客户资金转移到他的对冲基金，并向投资者和贷方撒谎。

;

;Bankman-Fried 预计将;作证;为自己辩护在两名简短的证人作证后，他的律师克里斯蒂安·埃弗德尔在陪审团不在场的法庭上说道。埃弗德尔说，第一批证人将是班克曼-弗里德在巴哈马的律师克里斯塔尔·罗尔（Krystal Rolle）和数据库专家约瑟夫·平布利（Joseph Pimbley）。

;

;对于班克曼-弗里德来说，出庭作证是一个冒险的举动，会给检察官带来机会。盘问这位 31 岁的前亿万富翁，询问他的前亲密同事的证词，称他指使他们犯罪。

;

;检方在提供 12 天的证词后搁置了案件，美国地区法官刘易斯 (Lewis)在案件提交陪审团之前，卡普兰拒绝了辩方要求释放班克曼-弗里德无罪的请求。辩护律师马克·科恩辩称，检察官没有提出电汇欺诈的“可行的法律理论”，检察官尼古拉斯·鲁斯对此提出异议。

;

; Thu, 26 Oct 2023 22:25:02 +0800 Companies may be employers of contract, franchise workers under US labor rulehttps://reuters.com/article/usa-labor/companies-may-be-employers-of-contract-franchise-workers-under-us-labor-rule-idUSKBN31Q1O5
;;2023-10-26T14:21:14Z;
;;
;;The seal of the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) is seen at their headquarters in Washington, DC, US, May 14, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo;
;

;A US labor board on Thursday issued a final rule making it easier for workers and unions to hold companies liable for labor law violations by their franchisees and contractors, reviving an Obama-era standard heavily criticized by trade groups.

;

;The rule from the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) will treat companies as so-called "joint employers" when they have control, even if it is indirect or not exercised, over essential terms and conditions of employment such as pay, scheduling, hiring and firing, and supervision.

;

;A company that is found to be a joint employer would likely be forced to become more involved in setting and implementing workplace policies, and could be required to bargain with unions.

;

;The rule takes effect on Dec. 26 and will only be applied to cases filed after that date.

;

;Joint employment has been one of the most contentious labor issues for many US businesses since the Obama administration, when the NLRB had adopted a similar standard that trade groups said was unworkable and would curb franchising.

;

;The new rule eliminates a regulation adopted during the Trump administration that was favored by business groups requiring companies to have "direct and immediate" control over contract and franchise workers in order to be considered joint employers.

;

;NLRB Chair Lauren McFerran in a statement called the new rule "a legally correct return to common-law principles" and a practical approach to ensure that the entities that effectively exercise control over workers' terms of employment respect their bargaining obligations.

;

;The rule will broadly affect industries such as manufacturing and construction that rely heavily on staffing agencies and contractors to provide workers, and franchises such as McDonald's ;(MCD.N); that are not typically involved in franchisees' day-to-day workplace issues.

;

;Business groups have said the rule would further complicate collective bargaining, making it more difficult for unions to negotiate contracts with businesses and undermining the NLRB's stated goal of strengthening workers' rights.

;

;Supporters of the new rule, including labor unions, have said the change is necessary because of an uptick in the use of contract labor, including workers provided by staffing agencies, in recent years.

;

;Worker advocates say companies have avoided being held accountable for labor violations under the more lax standard adopted during the Trump administration.

;

;That decline came after Alphabet's ;(GOOGL.O); shares logged their worst session since March 2020, dropping 9.5% as investors were disappointed with growth stalling in its cloud division. Amazon.com reports its results after the closing bell Thursday.

;

;In Europe, the ;European Central Bank; broke the longest streak of interest rate hikes in its 25-year history on Thursday, leaving its main rate at a record high of 4.0%, and saying the latest data continued to point to inflation slowly coming down to its 2% target.

;There was limited market reaction to the decision, and the euro was down 0.27% on the day.

;

;Europe's broad STOXX index was down 0.4%, just off seven-month lows hit earlier in the week ;(.STOXX);.

;

;MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan ;(.MIAPJ0000PUS); hit an 11-month low, down about 1.2%.

;

;;US news media reported on Wednesday night (October 25) that nearly two dozen people were killed in mass shootings in Lewiston, Maine, as authorities said a "person of interest" was at large, armed and dangerous, warning people there to shelter in place. Diane To reports.;
;

;Hundreds of police on Thursday fanned out across Maine looking for a gunman wanted for opening fire at a bar and a bowling alley in the city of Lewiston, with news outlets reporting a death toll ranging from 16 to 22, with dozens more wounded.

;

;Officials said there were multiple casualties in the Wednesday evening attack but declined to provide figures. Police told residents to stay indoors and schools across the area were closed on Thursday.

;

;State and local police identified Robert R. Card, who reportedly had been committed to a mental health facility over the summer, as a person of interest in the case. They circulated photographs of a bearded man in a brown hoodie and jeans at one of the crime scenes, holding what appeared to be a semi-automatic rifle in the firing position.

;

;"We have literally hundreds of police officers working around the state of Maine to investigate this case to locate Mr. Card, who is a person of interest," Maine Public Safety Commissioner Mike Sauschuck told a press conference.

;

;Police found a white SUV they believe Card drove to the town of Lisbon, about 7 miles (11 km) to the southeast, and Sauschuck said people were asked to remain indoors in both Lewiston and Lisbon. Early Thursday, Maine State Police also told residents in the town of Bowdoin, about 12 miles east of Lewiston, to shelter in place.

;

;Several media outlets reported that a Maine law enforcement bulletin identified Card, 40, as a trained firearms instructor and member of the US Army reserve who recently said he had been hearing voices and had other mental health issues, and that he threatened to shoot up a National Guard base.

;

;"Card was also reported to have been committed to mental health facility for two weeks during summer 2023 and subsequently released," said the notice from the Maine Information & Analysis Center, a unit of Maine State Police, according to NBC News. Reuters could not confirm the details reported in the bulletin.

;

;The army did not immediately respond to requests for information about Card, including details on his service record.

;

;Police said the shooting began shortly before 7 pm The Schemengees Bar & Grille Restaurant and the Just-in-Time Recreation bowling alley are about three miles (5 km) apart.

;

;"In a split second your world gets turn upside down for no good reason," Schemengees posted on its Facebook page. "How can we make any sense of this."

;

;Jessica Karcher said one of the wounded was her son Justin Karcher, who was shot in the spine and kidneys and was in surgery. He witnessed his father, Jean Karcher, being shot and killed in 2019 during an altercation in a Walmart parking lot, according to Lewiston's Sun Journal newspaper.

;

;In the Sun Journal account, Justin Karcher defended the right of firearm ownership, saying gun violence is "a people problem."

;

;Lewiston is a former textile hub and town of 38,000 people in Androscoggin County about 35 miles (56 km) north of Maine's largest city, Portland.

;

;Guns are lightly regulated in Maine, a largely rural state near the northeast border with Canada. It does not require a permit to buy or carry a gun, and it does not have so-called "red flag" laws seen in some other states that allow law enforcement to temporarily disarm people deemed to be dangerous.

;

;However, at least one federal judge has ruled such laws unconstitutional in light of a landmark 2022 decision by the US Supreme Court that said that the Constitution grants an individual the right to carry weapons in public.

;

;US President Joe Biden has spoken to state officials and offered the federal government's support, his office said.

;

;"This is a frightening, frightening situation," White House spokesman John Kirby told MSNBC. "More needs to be done to get these weapons of war off the streets and out of people's hands walking around Walmarts and grocery stores and bowling alleys."

;

;The range of estimated fatalities would be on par with the annual number of homicides that normally occur in Maine. The number of annual homicides in the state has fluctuated between 16 and 29 since 2012, according to Maine State Police.

;

;The number of US shootings in which four or more people were shot has surged since the COVID-19 pandemic began in 2020, with 647 occurring in 2022 and 679 projected to occur in 2023, based on trends as of July, according to data from the Gun Violence Archive.

;

;The deadliest modern US mass shooting on record is the massacre of 58 people by a gunman firing on a Las Vegas country music festival from a high-rise hotel perch in 2017.
